title: Preparation of Standard Solution of Oxalic Acid

stepDetails.description: Using an analytical balance, accurately weigh the calculated amount of oxalic acid dihydrate in a weighing bottle. Record the exact mass.
stepDetails.safety: Handle with care, avoid skin contact

stepDetails.title: calculate required amount of oxalic acid dihydrate
stepDetails.description: Transfer the weighed oxalic acid to a 100 mL beaker. Add about 50 mL of distilled water and stir with a glass rod until completely dissolved.

stepDetails.description: Mix oxalic acid with distilled water

title: Chemical Equilibrium
description: Investigate Le Chatelier's principle by observing how changes in concentration, temperature, and pressure affect chemical equilibrium. Study the cobalt(II) chloride equilibrium system.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Solutions
stepDetails.description: 1. Take a test tube and add a small amount of cobalt chloride crystals. 2. Add distilled water slowly and stir until it dissolves. 3. You will see a pink solution because of the hydrated [Co(HÔøΩÔøΩO)‚ÇÜ]¬≤‚Å∫ complex.

stepDetails.title: Add Concentrated HCl
stepDetails.description: Slowly add drops of concentrated HCl to the cobalt solution. Observe the color change from pink to blue as the equilibrium shifts.

stepDetails.title: Dilute with Water
stepDetails.description: Add distilled water to the blue solution. Observe the color change back to pink as the equilibrium shifts in the reverse direction.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Heating
stepDetails.description: Heat the pink solution in a water bath. Observe how increased temperature affects the equilibrium position and color.

stepDetails.title: Temperature Effect - Cooling
stepDetails.description: Cool the heated solution in an ice bath. Observe how decreased temperature shifts the equilibrium back.

stepDetails.title: Record Observations
stepDetails.description: Document all color changes and relate them to Le Chatelier's principle. Calculate equilibrium constants where applicable.

safetyInfo: Concentrated HCl is highly corrosive. Cobalt compounds are toxic if ingested. Always wear safety goggles, gloves, and work in a well-ventilated area. Handle hot and cold solutions with appropriate equipment.

title: To determine pH values of hydrochloric acid of different strengths using pH paper and universal indicator
description: Determine and compare the pH of hydrochloric acid solutions of varying concentrations using pH paper and a universal indicator solution. Learn safe handling of strong acids and how indicators reflect acidity.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Acid Solutions
stepDetails.description: Prepare three different strengths of hydrochloric acid solutions (for example: 0.1 M, 0.01 M, and 0.001 M) by appropriate dilution of a standard stock HCl solution using volumetric flasks and distilled water. Label each flask clearly.

stepDetails.title: Arrange Workspace and Safety
stepDetails.description: Put on safety goggles and gloves. Place beakers on a clean bench, keep a wash bottle handy, and ensure all containers are labeled. Work in a well-ventilated area or under a fume hood if available.
stepDetails.safety: Handle acids with care; avoid spills and skin contact

stepDetails.title: Measure pH with pH Paper
stepDetails.description: Dip a strip of universal pH paper into each acid solution, or place a drop of solution onto the pH paper. Compare the resulting color with the pH chart to estimate pH and record the value for each concentration.

stepDetails.title: Measure with Universal Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add a few drops of universal indicator solution to separate small aliquots of each acid strength in clean beakers. Observe and record the color change. Compare colors to the indicator color chart to determine pH range.

stepDetails.title: Compare and Analyze Results
stepDetails.description: Compare pH readings obtained from pH paper and universal indicator for each concentration. Note any discrepancies and discuss reasons (e.g., precision, indicator ranges, concentration effects).

stepDetails.title: Clean Up
stepDetails.description: Neutralize any small acid spills with sodium bicarbonate solution, rinse glassware thoroughly with distilled water, and properly dispose of used pH paper and indicator solutions as per laboratory guidelines.
stepDetails.safety: Neutralize spills immediately and dispose of waste safely

stepDetails.title: Record Observations and Conclusion
stepDetails.description: Prepare a short report listing prepared concentrations, measured pH values (from both methods), discuss accuracy and sources of error, and conclude on the relationship between HCl concentration and pH.

title: Determine the strength of a given solution of sodium hydroxide by titrating it against a standard solution of oxalic acid, having the strength 0.1N.
description: Determine the strength of a given solution of sodium hydroxide by titrating it against a standard solution of oxalic acid, having the strength 0.1N. Learn precise volumetric analysis techniques and endpoint detection.

stepDetails.title: Prepare the Setup
stepDetails.description: Set up the burette in the stand and rinse it with distilled water, then with the NaOH solution. Fill the burette with NaOH solution and adjust to zero mark.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Oxalic Acid Solution
stepDetails.description: Using a pipette, transfer exactly 25.0 mL of 0.1N oxalic acid solution into a clean conical flask. Place the flask on a white tile for better endpoint visibility.

stepDetails.title: Add Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add 2-3 drops of phenolphthalein indicator to the oxalic acid solution in the conical flask. The solution should remain colorless initially.

stepDetails.title: Initial Titration
stepDetails.description: Begin titrating by adding NaOH solution dropwise while swirling the flask continuously. The reaction is: H‚ÇÇC‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ + 2NaOH ÔøΩÔøΩ Na‚ÇÇC‚ÇÇO‚ÇÑ + 2H‚ÇÇO

stepDetails.title: Observe Color Change
stepDetails.description: Continue adding NaOH until a permanent light pink color appears that persists for 30 seconds. This indicates the endpoint. Record the burette reading.

stepDetails.title: Repeat Titrations
stepDetails.description: Perform at least 2 more concordant titrations to ensure accuracy. The volumes should agree within 0.1 mL for precise results.

stepDetails.title: Calculate Results
stepDetails.description: Calculate the average titre volume and determine the normality of NaOH solution using the formula: N‚ÇÅV‚ÇÅ = N‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇ, where N‚ÇÅV‚ÇÅ (oxalic acid) = N‚ÇÇV‚ÇÇ (NaOH).

stepDetails.title: Record and Analyze
stepDetails.description: Record all observations, calculate the average titre volume and determine the normality. Analyze the accuracy of your results and discuss sources of error.

safetyInfo: Sodium hydroxide is highly corrosive and can cause severe burns. Oxalic acid is toxic if ingested and can cause irritation. Always wear safety goggles and gloves. Handle all chemicals with care and wash hands thoroughly after handling. Work in a well-ventilated area.

title: Detection of Nitrogen, Sulphur, Chlorine, Bromine, and Iodine (Lassaigne's Test)
description: Perform Lassaigne's test to detect heteroatoms in organic compounds by preparing sodium fusion extract and carrying out confirmatory tests for nitrogen, sulphur, and halogens.

stepDetails.title: Safety and Setup
stepDetails.description: Wear goggles and gloves. Cut a small piece of dry sodium under kerosene. Set up ignition tube, tongs, and water beaker for quenching.
stepDetails.safety: Sodium reacts violently with water; handle under kerosene and use tongs.

stepDetails.title: Heat Organic Compound with Sodium
stepDetails.description: Add a small piece of sodium to the ignition tube. Add the organic compound. Heat strongly until the tube becomes red hot.

stepDetails.title: Quench and Prepare Extract
stepDetails.description: Plunge the hot tube into a beaker of distilled water wrapped in cloth. Boil and crush, then filter to obtain clear sodium fusion extract (Lassaigne's extract).

stepDetails.title: Test for Nitrogen (Prussian Blue)
stepDetails.description: To 2 mL extract add freshly prepared FeSO‚ÇÑ, boil, cool, acidify with dilute HCl, then add a few drops of FeCl‚ÇÉ. Formation of Prussian blue confirms nitrogen.

stepDetails.title: Alternate Nitrogen Confirmation
stepDetails.description: Cyanide test: To the extract add FeSO‚ÇÑ and FeCl‚ÇÉ, then acidify with H‚ÇÇSO‚ÇÑ/HCl; deep blue color indicates [Fe‚ÇÑ[Fe(CN)‚ÇÜ]‚ÇÉ] formation.

stepDetails.title: Test for Sulphur (Lead Acetate)
stepDetails.description: Acidify a portion of extract with acetic acid and add lead acetate solution. Black precipitate of PbS confirms sulphur.

stepDetails.title: Alternate Sulphur Test (Nitroprusside)
stepDetails.description: Add sodium nitroprusside to alkaline extract; purple/violet color indicates sulphide ions.

stepDetails.title: Remove Interference and Test for Halogens
stepDetails.description: Boil a fresh portion of extract with dilute HNO‚ÇÉ to decompose CN‚Åª/S¬≤‚Åª. Cool and add AgNO‚ÇÉ: white (Cl‚Åª), cream (Br‚Åª), or yellow (I‚Åª) precipitate.

stepDetails.title: Confirm Halogen by Ammonia Solubility
stepDetails.description: Treat the silver halide precipitate with NH‚ÇÉ: AgCl dissolves in dilute NH‚ÇÉ; AgBr dissolves in concentrated NH‚ÇÉ; AgI is insoluble.

safetyInfo: Perform sodium fusion with great care. Dry sodium under kerosene; never touch with wet hands. Use safety shield when heating. Handle acids, AgNO3, and ammonia with gloves and goggles. Dispose of silver waste properly.

title: To determine and compare pH of 0.01 M HCl and 0.01 M CH3COOH solution using universal indicator
description: Determine and compare the pH of 0.01 M HCl (strong acid) and 0.01 M CH3COOH (weak acid) using a universal indicator and color chart. Understand differences in acid strength and degree of ionization.

stepDetails.title: Label and Prepare Test Tubes
stepDetails.description: Label two clean test tubes as HCl and CH3COOH. Add about 5 mL of each 0.01 M solution to the respective tubes.

stepDetails.title: Add Universal Indicator
stepDetails.description: Add 2‚Äì3 drops of universal indicator solution to each test tube. Swirl gently to mix.
stepDetails.safety: Avoid contact with skin and eyes; indicator contains dyes/solvents.

stepDetails.title: Observe and Match Colors
stepDetails.description: Observe the color developed in each tube and compare with the standard pH color chart to estimate pH.

stepDetails.title: Record Estimated pH
stepDetails.description: Record the approximate pH for 0.01 M HCl and 0.01 M CH3COOH. Note that strong acids give lower pH than weak acids at the same molarity.

stepDetails.title: Compare with Expected Values
stepDetails.description: Compare observations with theoretical expectations: HCl (~pH 2) vs CH3COOH (typically higher pH, ~2.4‚Äì3.0 due to partial ionization).

stepDetails.title: Cleanup
stepDetails.description: Dispose of solutions as per guidelines and rinse glassware with plenty of water.

safetyInfo: Both acids are irritants; avoid contact with skin and eyes. Wear safety goggles and gloves. Do not ingest chemicals. Handle glassware carefully.

title: Preparation of Oxalic Acid
description: To prepare a standard solution of oxalic acid (preparation of 250 mL 0.1N oxalic acid solution).

stepDetails.title: Calculation & record
stepDetails.description: Calculate the required mass and record the calculation including molecular weight, target concentration and volume. Verify values before proceeding.

stepDetails.title: Weighing the reagent
stepDetails.description: Accurately weigh the calculated amount of oxalic acid dihydrate on an analytical balance. Record the exact mass and note any tare adjustments.
stepDetails.safety: Handle with care; avoid skin contact.

stepDetails.title: Transfer & dissolve
stepDetails.description: Transfer the weighed reagent to a beaker and add approximately 50 mL of distilled water. Stir with a glass rod until the solid is completely dissolved.

stepDetails.title: Transfer to volumetric flask & washings
stepDetails.description: Using a funnel, transfer the solution to a 250 mL volumetric flask. Rinse the beaker and funnel with distilled water and add the washings to the flask to ensure quantitative transfer.

stepDetails.title: Cool & make up to mark
stepDetails.description: Allow the flask to cool to room temperature if warm. Then add distilled water carefully until the bottom of the meniscus is exactly at the calibration mark.

stepDetails.title: Mix & equilibrate
stepDetails.description: Cap the volumetric flask and invert it 20‚Äì25 times to ensure thorough mixing and equilibration of the solution before use.

stepDetails.title: Labeling & documentation
stepDetails.description: Label the flask with concentration, reagent name and date. Document all observations and recorded masses in the lab notebook or digital log.

safetyInfo: Oxalic acid is toxic and corrosive. Avoid skin contact and inhalation. Wear safety goggles and gloves. Work in a well-ventilated area. Wash hands thoroughly after handling.

title: To study the change in pH of ammonium hydroxide solution on addition of ammonium chloride
description: Investigate how adding ammonium chloride (NH4Cl) to an ammonium hydroxide (NH4OH) solution affects pH. Observe the common-ion effect: adding NH4+ shifts the NH3/NH4+ equilibrium and lowers the pH.

stepDetails.title: Prepare 0.1 M NH4OH Solution
stepDetails.description: Prepare approximately 100 mL of 0.1 M ammonium hydroxide solution (NH4OH) using dilute ammonia solution. Record initial concentration and temperature.

stepDetails.title: Measure Initial pH
stepDetails.description: Calibrate the pH meter or prepare universal indicator. Measure and record the initial pH of the NH4OH solution (expect a basic pH due to NH3 in water).

stepDetails.title: Add NH4Cl Incrementally
stepDetails.description: Add small known amounts (e.g., 0.1 g increments) of solid ammonium chloride to the NH4OH solution. Stir thoroughly after each addition and allow the solution to equilibrate.

stepDetails.title: Record pH After Each Addition
stepDetails.description: Measure and record pH after each NH4Cl addition. Observe the pH dropping as NH4+ concentration increases and the common-ion effect suppresses NH3 ionization.

stepDetails.title: Analyze Results
stepDetails.description: Plot pH vs amount of NH4Cl added. Discuss the common-ion effect, buffer region behavior, and calculate expected pH changes using Kb for NH3 (Kb ‚âà 1.8√ó10‚Åª‚Åµ).

stepDetails.title: Cleanup and Safety
stepDetails.description: Neutralize and dispose solutions according to local guidelines. Rinse glassware thoroughly and wash hands. Store reagents properly.
stepDetails.safety: Ammonia vapors are irritating; work in well-ventilated area. Wear goggles and gloves.

safetyInfo: Ammonium hydroxide and ammonia vapors are irritating to eyes and respiratory tract. Ammonium chloride is an irritant. Work in a well-ventilated area or fume hood. Wear safety goggles, gloves, and avoid inhalation.

title: To study the change in pH of ethanoic acid on addition of sodium ethanoate
description: Explore how adding sodium ethanoate (CH‚ÇÉCOONa) to a solution of ethanoic acid (CH‚ÇÉCOOH) affects pH. Observe buffer formation and the common-ion effect; use measurements to apply the Henderson‚ÄìHasselbalch equation.

stepDetails.title: Prepare Ethanoic Acid Solution
stepDetails.description: Prepare approximately 100 mL of 0.1 M ethanoic acid (CH3COOH) in a beaker. Record initial concentration and temperature.

stepDetails.title: Measure Initial pH
stepDetails.description: Calibrate the pH meter or prepare universal indicator. Measure and record the initial pH of the ethanoic acid solution.

stepDetails.title: Add Sodium Ethanoate Incrementally
stepDetails.description: Add known small volumes (e.g., 0.5 mL increments) of 0.1 M sodium ethanoate solution to the acid solution. Stir and allow the solution to equilibrate after each addition.
stepDetails.safety: Avoid skin contact; handle reagents with care.

stepDetails.title: Record pH After Each Addition
stepDetails.description: Measure and record pH after each addition. Observe increase in pH as ethanoate ion concentration increases, showing buffer action.

stepDetails.title: Analyze with HendersonÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩHasselbalch
stepDetails.description: Use recorded concentrations and pH values to apply the Henderson‚ÄìHasselbalch equation and calculate pKa. Discuss how the common-ion effect stabilizes pH.

stepDetails.title: Cleanup and Safety
stepDetails.description: Neutralize and dispose solutions according to local guidelines. Rinse glassware thoroughly and wash hands. Store reagents properly.
stepDetails.safety: Ethanoic acid is an irritant and has a strong odor; work in a well-ventilated area. Wear goggles and gloves.

safetyInfo: Ethanoic acid (acetic acid) is an irritant and can cause respiratory discomfort at higher concentrations. Sodium ethanoate is generally low hazard but handle all chemicals with care. Always wear safety goggles and gloves; work in a ventilated area. Dispose of waste per guidelines.
